page.title: 02MYTON BRIDGE IN HULL
page.content: The Myton bridge is named after one of the oldest parts of Hull - dating back to 1160. The bridge forms part of a major inner city ring road development known as the South Orbital road. The new road is designed to ease city centre traffic. The bridge was opened in 1980 by the Lord Lieutenant of Humberside. As the bridge is over the River Hull and river traffic has historic precedence it must be raised at times to allow river traffic to pass. The bridge is quite unique in that it is about 1,000m long and is a 'counter balanced,unequal span,cable stayed,box girder,swing bridge. This bridge cost Â£8 million to build and is very busy as it takes docks traffic to and from the M62 and Humber bridge arterial routes.
